body:
This is a real bad one.

When enabling that root companion app thing, the main app exits abruptly. Then, there are two BetterBatteryStats icons in the app list. Starting the first shows a screen, saying that it’s a companion app that does nothing, and indeed it has no menus or anything. The second one just gives me a dialog, saying that it isn’t installed.

FDroid *now* also shows me there’s an update from 1.0.0.0 to 1.15.0.0 available.

But since it is a system app now, it can neither be uninstalled nor updated (due to supposedly being signed with a different key [WAT?]). Attempting to uninstall it, just results in an error with – of course – no reason given whatsoever.

And since the normal app is “gone”, I can’t undo the move to /system either.

Now what do I do?

This is probably the worst case scenario of a bug, apart from maybe deleting all data. ;)

Edit: For now, I have disabled the app, and will try “Wakelock detector” instead…

body:
There's really slowness when 'su --context' is used at SuperSU 2.22 for example.
This could be related to the fact that su --context call is performed within another su call, so there are effectively 2 nested shells at that time.
Try to avoid this nesting to see if that makes any difference.The impact on the UI is not my concern: if the time taken to save a reference is in the magnitude of a minute bbs will need to hold longer wakelocks and this will increase timing problems (two parts of a ref created one minute apart) 

And in longer term, performing all su calls outside the main thread is highly encouraged. That may actually also help with the UI responsiveness.

As an example, Autostarts application - sources at https://github.com/miracle2k/android-autostarts - makes use of both 'su --context' as well as separate threads for all su calls and doesn't have such sluggishness issues.

http://forum.xda-developers.com/showpost.php?p=56992011&postcount=26683

body:
At Android 5.0, system applications are installed in their own directories. BBS so far installs its system application into the main private system app directory. While it doesn't prevent it from functioning, it would be good to correct the installation location at Android 5.0 to conform to the new standard.

Example:
/system/priv-app/BetterBatteryStats/com.asksven.betterbatterystats.apk
or
/system/priv-app/BetterBatteryStats_xdaedition/com.asksven.betterbatterystats_xdaedition.apk

The application directory should have 0755 permissions.
The application package (apk) should have 0644 permissions.
Both directory and apk should have root:root ownership.
title: Adjust system app installation location at Android 5.0

Currently many errors (permissions etc.) are not surfaced to the user. This change addresses that by:
- adding a hidden field to the list that will be shown / populated with the reason why data was not available
- adding proper return codes / checks for file access (kernel wakelocks), permission issues (dumpsys with root), internal errors with the the battery info service


sqlite says:

```
sqlite> select time_created,ref_name,ref_label from samples order by time_created;
36906|ref_boot|Boot
3389934796|ref_unplugged|Unplugged
3389982064|ref_charged|Charged
3455728601|ref_screen_off|Screen Off
3483678536|ref_current|Current
```

As it turns out, these time_created values, which the app obtains via SystemClock.elapsedRealtime(), do not fit in a signed 32-bit integer.  It is necessary to use getLong() to extract this field from SQLite, as time_elapsed will exceed Integer.MAX_VALUE in about 25 days, and then getInt() will start returning negative numbers.  Negative values of timeCreated will cause (timeCreated > time) to be false for most reasonable values of time (including 0), resulting in much chaos.

The phone on which this problem was seen had not been rebooted in 40 days:

```
$ adb shell uptime
up time: 40 days, 09:30:28, idle time: 26 days, 09:46:03, sleep time: 26 days, 16:10:16
```

BTW: I was not successful in making a local build from the current head of tree, as the AndroidCommon repo is missing RootShell.java.  Could you please push your latest changes and make sure the tree is buildable from a "clean" checkout?

Thanks.

body:
This may or may not relate to bug #369

large_widget_default_stat_type and a couple of other preferences used to use numeric values (1, 2, 3, ...) to indicate the time reference (Unplugged, Boot, etc).  This was changed a while back, and migration code was added to update existing users, but on a fresh install the default values are still numeric.  This prevents the widgets from updating properly until the user manually overrides them.

If this happens, ReferenceStore.java:getReferenceByName() will print these errors to logcat:

    Reference 1 was not found
    Reference 3 was not found

The quick fix is to just modify preferences.xml; however there is precedent in StatsActivity.java for adding code to repair bad migrations on existing systems.

Proposed fix:

https://github.com/cernekee/BetterBatteryStats/commits/bug-372

Note that this also changes the widget fallback stat to ref_unplugged; this is consistent with the "fallback fix" in StatsActivity.java.
title: [bug] widgets do not update on a fresh installation

body:
A couple of minor issues were found when attempting to build BetterBatteryStats from the github source trees:

1) AndroidCommon was missing two resource files.  This was remedied by copying them in from the unpacked apk.

2) Commit ca022e131 (Refactored all operations to handle from/to references) made callers to trackStats() pass explicit from/to strings instead of just a stat type.  However, trackStats() was not updated to match the new API.  This was remedied by decompiling the apk, adding the missing function to the source tree, and tweaking the formatting for consistency.

3) In general, it took a bit of work to track down all of the dependencies.  I would propose the following changes:

 - Use git submodules to fetch the AndroidCommon library

 - Add the LocalePluginLib and ActionBarSherlock libraries into the repo (both are Apache-licensed)

 - Add rudimentary build instructions to README

These changes have been implemented here - feel free to pull anything that looks appropriate:

https://github.com/cernekee/BetterBatteryStats/commits/bug-371
https://github.com/cernekee/AndroidCommon/commits/bug-371

body:
when a user has not granted root rights to bbs for performing alarms / network but root features are active then this happens? That would mean that the "su" call gets stuck and waits forever to get access perms instead of the call being terminated and ended with a permissions denied. If I got you correctly we may have a look into superuser/supersu as this would be very bad: if nothing happens there are no errors but the service creating the reference would stay stuck forever and finally be terminated due to a timeout without me getting the possibility to release the wakelock (maye I will look into the status model of services to see if there is a hook for termination.

If would be great if you could confirm for me to open an issue, tell me what supersu/superuser version you are using and maybe provide a logcat. I will also try to reproduce once you confirm that I got you right (or not if you tell me I am completely wrong).
You got me right, latest su binaries with supersu app.

Answer:
The funny thing is, I updated bbs as user.

The wl appeared. I disabled the root features, wl was gone, some time later I switched the user to the main one (root)

Even I didn't install rc5 with this user, supersu asked for root and the version was up to date... weird?

But, it's a known issue for both su implementations that multi user support is not given yet.

We had the same problem in the past with other people complaining about infinite wakelock from bbs on android prior jelly bean, in that case I assume a dirty root implementation. (Rooted via update.zip in stock recovery).

body:
I think the filter of the "from" and "to" spinners still need some fine tuning. I found a couple of situations:

- If you select "Current" in From, then the To spinner doesn't show any options. Should it be possible to use "Current" in From?
- In some refresh situations (at least when setting custom ref and when screen is turned off then on), if the app was left open with Current in From then the To will be populated with all entries, and (at least in my case) it will go to Boot. Current->Boot doesn't make sense, and neither does it for any other To.
- "From Custom" seems to be properly filtering the possible To's. It presented me with Current and Screen Off, and after plugging/unplugging I also got Unplugged since it's more recent. Likewise, after doing this having From Unplugged no longer displays To Custom since it's older.

Perhaps you can double check the code that lists the possible values of From so it doesn't list any entry that would have an empty To list.
Also, when something is refreshed (e.g. screen off/on) the From spinner might also need to be changed.

body:
Replace personal information in well-known entries of the dump files.
Example: partial wakelock entries like "*sync*_xxxx{name=<email or username> type=yyy}..." where xxx is the app (gmail, G+, github, ...) and yyy is the account type (google, github, ...)
When replacing the email or username in such entries, distinct values should still be preserved so it yields the information that there's an email account syncing gmail, G+, a second account of the same type syncing gmail, greader, etc.

With this in place users would not be as exposed as now if they don't wish to share these personal entries, and no need to edit dump files before posting - at least not for these expected entries.

body:
For items that are related to particular packages, like:
- Alarms
- Network usage
- Process
- Event-nnn KWLs
- Partial WLs (if exposed by the service)

Show in the dump and/or on the display (popup when clicking?) information about the various autorun triggers of that package.
Well-known packages might have a startup behavior already common knowledge to a few folks but:
- not to the "normal users"
- additional packages have unknown behavior
- even the well-known packages might have been blocked (perhaps partially) on each devices using existing tools

body:
When you browse trough the different screens in BBS, it updates the screen every time you change it. When you want to check the last standby values, BBS "records" events that occur while reading BBS information. So my drain measurement values become more and more wrong while browsing BBS pages.

So me came just the idea, if there could be implemented such thing like a Auto-Freeze option on ... maybe switch-on/unlock/BBS-open. So that BBS just show events until switch-on/unlock/BBS-open, don't care how long you browse trough the BBS pages. So studying BBS pages wont change your values, cause value-recording is frozen at that time.

body:
from cdmackay @ xda 
Wake locks relating to a service are converted to deleted_wake_locks if that service goes away.

The common cause is when you disable wifi: then the wifi-related wake locks (like wlan_wake, etc), all get lumped together as deleted_wake_locks.

also add ref to: http://forum.xda-developers.com/showpost.php?p=27227201&postcount=5644

I'm not sure whether this applies to any service other than wifi, but that's when I see it.
title: [feature] add deleted_wake_locks

body:
Guys for all of you, the eventx-xxxx is the Android system server!
The digits are only the PID (Process IDentifier), therefore the number is always a different one.

Means this is the famous Android OS visible in the stock battery monitor application.

Google masquerades the internal processes this way.

So we don't have any insight which part of the system triggers the particular wakelock, an assumption what might be one cause is fast dormancy and scheduled background processes like alarm clock and sync/update activity (market/maps).
title: [feature] add kb and functionality for eventxxxx kwl

ArrayList shortHistory is a subset of m_histList which does not contain
points with the same battery level value. This serves two purposes:
- improve performance
- remove stairs in case when device was in the sleep mode for a long time
(Android logs an old value when he resumes from sleep, so if device was
asleep for 36 hours, after resume battery level will be looged the same as
before and then immediately next value.)

body:
Suddenly the penny drops - I think. I believe I am correct in interpreting the three options as showing the time that the offending process has had a wakelock in place, expressed as a percentage of:
1) the time in the displayed measurement period that the phone has not been plugged in
2) the time in the displayed measurement period that the phone has been awake
3) the time in the displayed measurement period that the phone has been awake less the time that the screen was on
I hadn't twigged that the "-" in "% of time awake - time with screen on" meant "minus". Could the whole dialogue be re-worded to make it clearer? For example, the heading could be "Wakelock expressed as % of time..." and the three options could be "on battery", "awake", "awake, minus screen-on time".

Or maybe I'm just too thick for it to be worthwhile pandering to my stupidity  since no-one else has had any problem understanding what it meant.
title: [feature] Wording of wakelock pct settings

body:
I've got a few more oddities, if you don't mind:

1) I understand about not using the "back" button if you want to keep the custom reference. If I've been off doing other things and then return to BBS by long-pressing the home key and selecting BBS from the list, it does indeed remember the custom reference. If, however, I go in to the app drawer and click on the BBS icon, or if I have the icon on the home page and click on that, it gives me the "no custom reference set" warning.

2) When it gives me the "no custom reference set" warning, the display still seems to be based on some kind of reference point, usually further back in time than "last unplugged" but not as far back as "since charged" (which we know on Froyo is something different anyway).

3) Sometimes the display does not re-draw fully when you come out of the preferences screen. Usually I get the two option bars but no data underneath. This seems to fix itself if I pop in to the help page and back out.

4) I've no clear idea exactly what sequence of actions I had followed before this one occurred, but the other day after running BBS for quite a while and having set a few custom references during that time, I hit the back key to come out. Instead of exiting the app, the dispay re-drew with data based on an older custom reference. I hit the back key again and another set of custom reference data was displayed, based on another, yet older custom reference. I ended up having going back through about six screens of data, each based on successively older custom references, before the application finally exited.

Actually, I could almost see that last one as being a feature, if it could be reliably reproduced...
title: [bug] inconsistent behavior when hitting "back"

body:
nobnut
What I am thinking is maybe a widget that is updated only after a minimum period of sleep and then remains static until after the device wakes up from sleep again (minimum sleep period perhaps 30 minutes). This way it will not cause any wake time as it only updates after the device wakes up 

Similar to the BBS main app, the widget could display:

- Top 3 or 5 apps/services causing wakelock since screen off
- In ranked order
- Perhaps the apps could be colour coded if certain thresholds are exceeded (e.g. > 30% of sleep potential prevented is Red... > 20% is Orange... < 20% is Blue)
- The user can perhaps specify the thresholds and colours via the in app menu

Click on the widget and... whatever you want (open BBS/open battery statistics/open Manage Applications etc).

This might be easier for users than going in to the main BBS app to see the 'worst offending apps' and would present an ongoing glimpse into what causes wake on their devices.

I know I would certainly love this feature and would be more than happy to pay for it via the Market, which I fully intend to do even if there is a free version on XDA
title: [feature] Widget
